description:
The **AWSSupport-TroubleshootOpenSearchHighCPU** runbook provides an automated solution to collect diagnostic data from your Amazon OpenSearch Service (AOS) domain to troubleshoot high CPU issues. The runbook collects the following data from your AOS domain.

> * Hot threads information
> * Detailed information about the currently executing tasks
> * Thread pool statistics for each node in the domain
> * Information about the nodes in the domain sorted by their CPU usage in descending order
> * Shard allocation to each data node and their disk space
> * Health status and basic information about the health of OpenSearch domain

### Note:
By default, this runbook automates the collection of five data samples every 3 seconds and saves it to Amazon CloudWatch Logs for up to 24 hours. You can control the number and seconds between data samples to be collected by specifying a custom value for `NumberOfDataSamples` and `NumberOfSecondsBetweenSamples` input parameters. You can also retain the output in the Amazon CloudWatch Logs for up to 30 days by specifying the number of days in the `DataRetentionDays` input parameter.

### How does it work?

> * This runbook runs the [DescribeDomain](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/voiceid/latest/APIReference/API_DescribeDomain.html) API to get details about your OpenSearch domain.
> * Checks whether the OpenSearch is public or virtual private cloud (VPC) based.
> * Creates a public or [VPC based](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/foundation-networking.html) AWS Lambda function using an AWS CloudFormation stack.
> * The AWS Lambda function is responsible for fetching diagnostic data from your Amazon OpenSearch Service domain.
> * In order to gather a more comprehensive dataset for troubleshooting high CPU issues, the runbook orchestrates the execution of the AWS Lambda function multiple times, this is achieved through the use of an AWS Step Function that is also created using CloudFormation.
> * The collected data is stored in an Amazon CloudWatch log group.
> * Deletes the created resources except for the Amazon CloudWatch log group.

### Prerequisites:

Before you start the runbook, you need a service role (automation assume role) and an Access Management (IAM) IAM role for the Lambda function. 

#### Automation assume role:
> * Trust relationship:
```
{

            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {
                "Service": "ssm.amazonaws.com"
            },
            "Action": "sts:AssumeRole"
        }
    ]
}
```
> * Permission required to manage the Amazon CloudWatch, AWS Lambda function, OpenSearch domain, VPC, IAM, and AWS Step Function
```

    "Statement": [
        {

                "arn:aws:es:<region>:<account>:domain/<domain-name>/_task*",
                "arn:aws:es:<region>:<account>:domain/<domain-name>/_cat/nodes*",
                "arn:aws:es:<region>:<account>:domain/<domain-name>/_cat/allocation*",
                "arn:aws:es:<region>:<account>:domain/<domain-name>/_cat/thread_pool*"

        }
    ]

```

For instructions about creating an execution role for AWS Lambda see [Lambda execution role](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-intro-execution-role.html)

### Important:
For Amazon OpenSearch domains with *fine-grained access control* enabled, please make sure that the *LambdaExecutionRoleForOpenSearch* role is mapped to the OpenSearch dashboard role with at least `cluster_monitor` permissions. Steps to map the role:
> * Login to the OpenSearch Dashboards with master user credentials
> *> Select the navigation three-line menu at the top left corner
> * Under OpenSearch Plugins choose **Security**.
> * Select **Roles**.
> * Select the role with minimum of `cluster_monitor` permissions, for example `readall_and_monitor`.
> * Select **Manage Mapping**.
> * In the **Backend roles** section paste the ARN you are specifying in the `LambdaExecutionRoleForOpenSearch` parameter and choose **map**.

For more information on managing permissions and role mapping, see [Fine-grained access control in Amazon OpenSearch Service](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/fgac.html#fgac-access-control)

### Important:

> * This runbook creates the following resources in your account during invocation. These resources may incur additional costs.
> * An AWS Lambda function to collect data from the AOS domain. See [AWS Lambda Pricing](https://aws.amazon.com/lambda/pricing/).
> * An AWS Step Function state machine to orchestrate the data collection. See [AWS Step Functions Pricing](https://aws.amazon.com/step-functions/pricing/).
> * An Amazon CloudWatch log group to store the data collected by the AWS Lambda function. See [Amazon CloudWatch Pricing](https://aws.amazon.com/cloudwatch/pricing/).

#### Note:
All the resources except for the CloudWatch Logs log group are deleted by the automation at the end of the run. The log group is not deleted automatically and the logs are retained for the number of days you specify in the `DataRetentionDays` parameter. You must delete the log group manually after troubleshooting the high CPU issue.
> * The maximum number of data samples you can collect using this automation is limited to 10.
> * You can save the data in CloudWatch Logs for a maximum of 30 days. If you want to retain the data more than 30 days, you need to export it to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. For more information, see [Export log data to Amazon S3 using the console](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudWatch/latest/logs/S3ExportTasksConsole.html).

AutomationAssumeRole.description: (Optional) The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that allows Systems Manager Automation to perform the actions on your behalf. If no role is specified, Systems Manager Automation uses the permissions of the user that starts this runbook.

DomainName.description: (Required) The name of the Amazon OpenSearch domain that you want to troubleshoot for high CPU issues.

LambdaExecutionRoleForOpenSearch.description: (Required) The ARN of the IAM role to attach to the AWS Lambda function. The AWS Lambda function uses the credentials from this role to sign requests to your AOS domain. If *fine-grained access control (FGAC)* are enabled on your AOS domain, you must map this role to the OpenSearch Dashboards backend role with minimum of `cluster_monitor` permissions.

LambdaInvocationRoleForStepFunctions.description: (Optional) The ARN of the IAM role to attach to the AWS Step Functions workflow. The state machine uses the credentials from this role to invoke the Lambda function that fetches diagnostic data from the AOS domain. If no role is specified, this automation will create an IAM role for Step Functions in your account.

DataRetentionDays.description: (Optional) The number of days to retain the diagnostic data collected from the AOS domain. By default, the data is retained for `24` hours (1 day). You can choose to retain the data for a maximum of up to `30` days.

NumberOfDataSamples.description: (Optional) The number of data samples to collect from the AOS domain. By default, `5` data samples are collected. You can collect up to `10` samples. The AWS Lambda function is invoked for each sample collection.

NumberOfSecondsBetweenSamples.description: (Optional) The number of seconds between data samples. By default, `3` seconds.

import sys

import boto3
from botocore.exceptions import ClientError

sys.tracebacklimit = 0


def function_handler(events, context):
    """
    AWS Lambda function to describe an Amazon OpenSearch domain.

    Args:
        events : AWS Lambda event input containing the "DomainName" key.
        context: AWS Lambda context object (unused).

    Returns:
        dict: A dictionary containing information about the OpenSearch domain, including
              its endpoint, ARN, subnet IDs, security group IDs, and VPC ID.

    Raises:
        Exception: If there is an error during the domain description or execution.
    """
    aos_client = boto3.client("opensearch")

    try:
        # DescribeDomain
        domain_status = aos_client.describe_domain(DomainName=events["DomainName"]).get("DomainStatus")

        # Creating an empty dictionary to store the results
        result = {}

        # here if condition is required as the for vpc domain the value of endpoint is stored in Endpoints and for non-vpc its in Endpoint
        if "Endpoint" in domain_status:
            result["Endpoint"] = domain_status.get("Endpoint", "")
        else:
            result["Endpoint"] = domain_status["Endpoints"].get("vpc", "")

        result["ARN"] = domain_status.get("ARN", "")
        result["SubnetIds"] = ",".join((domain_status.get("VPCOptions", {})).get("SubnetIds", []))
        result["SecurityGroupIds"] = ",".join((domain_status.get("VPCOptions", {})).get("SecurityGroupIds", []))
        result["VpcId"] = (domain_status.get("VPCOptions", {})).get("VPCId", "")
    except ClientError as error:
        raise RuntimeError(
            f"[ERROR] An error occurred when describing the AWS OpenSearch domain {str(error)}"
        ) from None

    return result

\
          import http.client

import logging

import os

import time

from\

from urllib.parse import\
          \ urlparse



import botocore.session

from botocore.auth import SigV4Auth

          \ session

session = botocore.session.Session()

\
          
logger = logging.getLogger()

logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)




\
          
def request_opensearch(domain_endpoint, path="", filters=""):

\
          \    """

    Make a request to OpenSearch.



    Args:

  \
          \      domain_endpoint (str): The OpenSearch domain endpoint.

      \
          \  path (str): The path to append to the URL.

        filters (str):\
          \ Additional filters for the request.



    Returns:

        dict:\
          \ A dictionary containing the response text.



    """

    region\
          \ = os.environ.get("AWS_REGION")

    sigv4 = SigV4Auth(session.get_credentials(),\
          \ "es", region)

    endpoint = domain_endpoint + path + filters

\
          \    request = AWSRequest(method="GET", url=endpoint)



    if "\
          :desc" in filters:

        request.url += "&s=cpu:desc"



  \
          \  if "queue,rejected,completed" in filters:

        request.url +=\
          \ "?v=true&h=id,name,active,queue,rejected,completed"



    sigv4.add_auth(request)
\
          
    prepped = request.prepare()



    url_parse = urlparse(endpoint)
\
          
    path_and_query = url_parse.path if url_parse.query is None else url_parse.path\
          \ + "?" + url_parse.query

    connection = http.client.HTTPSConnection(url_parse.hostname)\
          \  # nosec B309

    connection.request(prepped.method, path_and_query,\
          \ headers=prepped.headers)

    response = connection.getresponse()

\
          \    return {"response_text": response.read().decode()}





def\
          \ check_accessibility(api_name, url, max_retries=3):

    """

 \
          \   Check the accessibility of an OpenSearch API with retry.



   \
          \ Args:

        api_name (str): The name of the API being checked.

\
          \        url (str): The URL of the API.

        max_retries (int): Maximum\
          \ number of retry attempts.



    Returns:

    str: The response\
          \ data from the API.

    """

    retries = 0

    while retries\
          \ < max_retries:

        try:

            response = request_opensearch(url)
\
          
            response_data = response["response_text"]

          \
          \  return response_data

        except Exception as e:

          \
          \  log_message = f"Attempt {retries + 1} - An error occurred: {e}"

\
          \            # Log the error message and sleep for a short duration before\
          \ retrying

            logger.info(log_message)

            time.sleep(2)
\
          
            retries += 1



    # If all retry attempts fail, return\
          \ an error message

    return f"Max retries ({max_retries}) reached.\
          \ Could not access the API: {api_name}"





def function_handler(events,\
          \ context):

\

    outputs = []

          \ urls.values()))

    except Exception as e:

        log_message =\
          \ f"An error occurred: {e}"

        outputs = [log_message] * len(urls)
\
          


    output = []



    output.append(f"{index}. Iteration")
\
          
    output.append("Health status and basic information about the health\
          \ of OpenSearch domain:")

    output.append(outputs[0])



    output.append("\
          Shard allocation to each data node and their disk space:")

    output.append(outputs[1])
\
          


    output.append("Information about the nodes in the domain sorted\
          \ by their CPU usage in descending order:")

    output.append(outputs[2])
\
          


    output.append("Threadpool Statistics for each node in the domain:"\
          )

    output.append(outputs[3])



    output.append("Hot Threads\
          \ information:")

    output.append(outputs[4])



    output.append("\
          Currently executing tasks:")

    output.append(outputs[5])



 \
          \   logger.info("\n".join(output[:204800]))

    if len(output) > 204800:
\
          
        print("[WARNING] The output has been truncated. Please reduce\
          \ the number of samples.")



    index += 1

    return {

  \
          \      "numberofdatasamples": number_of_data_samples,

        "index"\
          : index,

        "opensearchdomainendpoint": opensearch_domain_endpoint,
\
          
        "continue": index <= number_of_data_samples,

        "response"\
          : f"Hot threads data collection interation {index} completed.",

  \
          \  }

"

import sys

def function_handler(events, context):
    partition = context["global:AWS_PARTITION"]
    region = context["global:REGION"]
    stack_name = events["StackName"]
    expected_stack_status = events["ExpectedStackStatus"]
    non_expected_resource_status = events["NonExpectedStackStatus"].split(",")
    console_url = get_stack_url(stack_name, partition, region)
    stackfailurereasons(stack_name, console_url, expected_stack_status, non_expected_resource_status)


def stackfailurereasons(
    stack_name,
    console_url,
    expected_stack_status,
    non_expected_resource_status,
):
    # Find events different than 'DELETE_COMPLETE' in the list of recent stack events
    # to get failure reason
    stack_failure_msg = []
    stack_failure_msg.append(
        f"\n\nThe AWS CloudFormation '{stack_name}' stack is not in '{expected_stack_status}' status.\n"
    )
    if expected_stack_status == "DELETE_COMPLETE":
        stack_failure_msg.append("Try to delete the CloudFormation stack from the AWS CloudFormation console.\n\n")
        stack_failure_msg.append(f"CloudFormation stack: {console_url}\n")
        stack_failure_msg.append("For more information on deleting a stack see ")
        stack_failure_msg.append(

        if e.response["Error"]["Code"] == "ValidationError" and "does not exist" in str(e):

            )
            print(repr(stack_success_msg))
            return stack_success_msg
        else:
            print(f"An error occurred when trying to describe the CloudFormation stack '{stack_name}': {str(e)}\n")
        print("".join(stack_failure_msg))
        sys.exit(1)

def get_stack_url(stack_name: str, partition: str, aws_region: str) -> str:
    domain_url_mapping = {
